07 May 2016

Testing Forrest Gump's chocolate box credo: do you really never know what you're gonna get?

by Lia Prins Forrest Gump was wrong. There is a way to know what you‚Äôre going to get in a box of chocolates‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämostly. This time of year, at least in the US, the gift packages and treats come flying in (sometimes literally) from vendors and customers. People are saying ‚Äúthank you‚Äù or ‚Äúhey, how about sending some more business our way‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand they‚Äôre doing it the international language of business : food.
  #chocolates   #design   #all   #lollipop

The most commonly used phrase in this language is the classic assorted box of chocolates. Sure, it‚Äôs a nice gesture. Most people enjoy chocolate candies. They don‚Äôt need to be cut (although this would help us by revealing their cros-sections , chilled, prepared, and they are less likely to cause guilt, due to their diminutive size.

But the box of chocolates comes with baggage‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe anxiety of the unknown. We‚Äôve all been there. You mosey on into the break-room and see a surprise box of chocolates. You‚Äôre not an animal, so you‚Äôre going to indulge. But you can‚Äôt stand the thought of biting into the raspberry creme one, or worse, the monstrosity that is the cherry cordial. You so badly want the chocolate or vanilla buttercream, the nougat, or the caramel one. But the thought of biting into the chocolate with the orange creme sends you into a bout of existential vertigo.

Fear not, friends, I have stumbled upon a very simple rule to help you navigate through the box of chocolates: If the candy is square and tall, you are safe‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs bound to be a non-fruit filled candy. If it‚Äôs round, it will tend to be fruit creme filled. Try it at your own risk.

Now, some boxes of chocolates come with guides‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa printed paper that shows how the treats are laid out in the box, with their shapes, and tells you what‚Äôs in them. This is great, and if you encounter a box with a guide, you can safely dive in. But it is not the common practice. The square/circle rule can help you to pick what you‚Äôre looking for in the absence of a guide. I‚Äôm here to help, and I hope this principle has helped you. Let me know how it works for you this holiday season.

Glossary
cross-section  

The interior sideview created by slicing, hypothetically or actually.
